Panama - Segundo Proyecto de Desarrollo Ganadero

abstracts.cdata!:
The Second Livestock Development Project
            was designed to continue providing credit for livestock
            (beef and milk) production. The emphasis of the second
            project was on milk rather than beef production in an effort
            to reduce milk imports. The project was to provide credit
            for: (a) dual-purpose (beef/dairy) farms (220 individual
            farms and 20 farmer groups); (b) 135 dairy farms; and (c) a
            government-owned breeding station that was to serve as a
            training center for farmers. Lessons learned include: 1) the
            project illustrates the need for a flexible approach during
            implementation. Because of difficulties in revising milk
            legislation, credit demand from dairy farms was low. At the
            same time, demand for beef production credit was high. Faced
            with this reality, the Bank allowed Banco Nacional de Panama
            (BNP) to provide credit for breeding/fattening farms to
            ensure that lending continued. Although the project as
            implemented varied somewhat from its design, the return on
            the investment was satisfactory, as evidenced by the
            economic rate of return of 11 percent; 2) the overall
            success of investments on private farms under the credit
            component and the failure of the government dairy program
            suggest that future lending of this type should concentrate
            on private farms; and 3) the smaller than anticipated
            improvements in technical coefficients suggest that the
            appraisal team was over-optimistic about the viability of
            upgrading the local herd. This indicates the need to assess
            more realistically what technical improvements are desirable
            and achievable through such a credit project.
